org.tantalum

Class AsyncTask

  • java.lang.Object
    • org.tantalum.Task
      • org.tantalum.AsyncTask
  • All Implemented Interfaces:
    java.lang.Runnable

    public abstract class AsyncTask
extends Task
    An implementation of Android's AsyncTask pattern for cross platform application on JME and Android. On Android it is intended as a drop-in replacement for the platform library class. The less commonly used features of the Android implementation are not supported. Unlike the Android version, you can join() or jointUI() a Tantalum AsyncTask to trigger out-of-sequence execution or wait a specified max time interval for the AsyncTask to complete. This design pattern is from Java 7's fork-join framework, but instead of using for server scalability we use it here for convenience in improving client side user experience.

    • Method Detail

      • disableAgressiveThreading

        public static void disableAgressiveThreading()
        When you call this, it means you don't want this object to be simultaneously on both the background worker task queue and the UI task queue. Call this one time for complete, conservative (but lower performance) compatability with all Android SDK versions. You may also want to call this if your suspect your AsyncTasks are not thread safe (!) The Android threading model has changed over time back and forth between different release versions, apparently because many programmers with using AsyncTask without making their code thread safe.

      • execute

        public static void execute(java.lang.Runnable runnable)
        For compatability with Android, run one Runnable task on a single background thread. Execution is guaranteed to be in the same order objects are queued.
        Parameters:
        runnable -

      • execute

        public final AsyncTask execute(java.lang.Object params)
        Run the async task on a single background thread. Note that this may be slower than executeOnExecutor() but is preferred if you require execution in the order in which execute() is called, or if execute() is not thread-safe such that multiple execute() calls can not run in parallel.
        Parameters:
        params -
        Returns:

      • executeOnExecutor

        public final AsyncTask executeOnExecutor(java.lang.Object params)
        Run the async task on a background thread pool, using the next available thread. Execution order is not guaranteed, but this may return results faster than execute() due to multi-core processors and concurrence benefits during blocking IO calls. This method must be invoked on the UI thread
        Parameters:
        params -
        Returns:
